Expectation1: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation1: A client has sent a standard contract for a routine service engagement that is not due back for quite some time.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I sat at my desk, the contract open on my screen, its clauses familiar and unthreatening. My client had sent it early, and there was no rush—plenty of time to review, annotate, and send it back. Still, I felt the usual tug of responsibility; as a lawyer, I prided myself on being thorough and prompt, never letting a document sit untouched. Just as I began to read, my phone buzzed. It was David from the synagogue. There was a funeral prayer in an hour, and they were one person short for the minyan. Without me, the prayer couldn’t happen, and the grieving family would be left waiting, unable to say Kaddish for their loved one. I stared at the contract, then at my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My professional self urged me to stay, to get ahead on my work, to be the reliable lawyer my clients expected. But my Jewish self felt the pull of community, of tradition, of not letting others down in their moment of need. The clock ticked, and I sat frozen, torn between two duties that both felt essential.
